tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): In regards to  (SPOILER) challenging his fate as a l'Cie , which involves him opposing the group that he's supposed to help.
[Kung-Fu Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KungFuWizard): He fights entirely using his l'cie magic and martial arts.

[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter): The Cid of *XIII*, and one who shakes up his traditional characterisation. Most Cids are heroic [clever inventors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius) who usually provide the airship or flying transport for the party, and some were/are playable characters. Dr. Cid Bunansa from [the previous game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXII) broke the trend somewhat by being an antagonist, albeit one with good intentions who retained his association with airships and inventing. Cid Raines is an [Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero), and a soldier (though a [smart one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser)) who never so much as picks up a toolbox, never mind inventing something; the fact his troops happen to work on airships is, along with his name, the only real tie he has to other versions of Cid.
[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): Like Snow, he is a brawler with great speed and endurance.

[Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood): His uniform is primarily white with some dark greys. Initially, the party doesn't know if they can trust him, but when he wins them over by revealing his intentions to rebel against the Sanctum, it becomes [Light Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsGood).  (SPOILER) But really, it signifies that he's been untrustworthy all along and has merely been ferrying them around at Dysley's orders.

[Noble Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon):  (SPOILER) 'Demon' is a big stretch, but shortly before he battles the party, he gives Lightning's gunblade back to her (via throw), having took it from her minutes ago.
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): Upon confronting the party,  (SPOILER) he transforms into a creature with *six* wings and tries to kill them.
[Power Gives You Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGivesYouWings): Six of them, in fact, in L'Cie form.
[Screw Destiny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny):  (SPOILER) He turns his back on his Focus in order to stop the hero party.

[Shadow Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowArchetype): He can easily be described as the Anti-Snow. He's idealistic, but it was turned against him. Wants to defy his fate, but is forced to follow it. Fights with his fists. The only thing missing is a short fiancée.  (SPOILER)  Snow himself later goes Cie'th himself, interestingly on the opposite arm to Cid.Their Cie'th forms in general play with this, especially with how they both go through an extra transformation during their battles. Cid has a more angelic themed form while Snow has a more demonic form.
[Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop):  (SPOILER)  Asks his subordinate to shoot him because he can't die otherwise.
[You Can't Fight Fate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCantFightFate):  (SPOILER) He becomes a crystal for his efforts and is later revived, but still kept under Barthandelus' control .
[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist):  (SPOILER) His reason for attacking you is because it's your Focus to destroy Cocoon .

[Adaptive Ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptiveAbility): For his battle in *XIII-2* he can paradigm shift just like the hero party. He can use the [Commando](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAttackAttack), [Sentinel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrawAggro), and [Saboteur](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects) roles, and uses grenades in lieu of magic or manadrives.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): He doesn't use any magic or even [manadrives](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicFromTechnology) when the hero party fights him, just his gun, some grenades and his bare hands.
[BFG](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFG): His weapon is a gigantic [gatling gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GatlingGood) with a massive bayonet.
[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): He's an expert at trivia games as well as a powerful soldier.
[Interservice Rivalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterserviceRivalry): He makes mention of how he dislikes the PSICOM division of the military.
[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): He is a very powerful ally if you can get him to join your paradigm pack in *XIII-2* but he's not the quickest.

[More Dakka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreDakka): In *XIII-2*, he can't jump after a Launched or otherwise airborne target, so he'll sit on the ground and fire at them with his gatling gun. For context, the passive ability Attack: ATB Charge II refills one-sixth of an ATB segment per hit; Amodar fills an entire segment per use of Attack when firing if he's been infused with the ability.
[Throw Down the Bomblet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowDownTheBomblet): He uses a lot of annoying grenades in battle which can inflict [Status Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusEffects).
[Pistol-Whipping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PistolWhipping): Although it's a pretty damn big gun to smack someone with!

[Rapid-Fire Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapidFireFisticuffs): His Iron Bear Claw [Feral Link](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak). The attack itself is a [Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut) to Akuma's Raging Demon attack from *[Street Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StreetFighter)*.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): See's NORA's technically illegal monster hunting as well meaning and lets them do their part in defending Bodhum and is a good boss for the troubled Lightning.
[Stout Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoutStrength): He is heavy but physically he is very strong.

[Subordinate Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubordinateExcuse): [Maaya Sakamoto](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/MaayaSakamoto) admitted to playing Lightning as though she had a crush on her superior officer. This was because the scene was recorded when Amodar's design hadn't been finalized yet, and in the beta version of the scene that Sakamoto was using as a reference, Amodar was actually a [young handsome man wearing a Hawaiian shirt.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice) She was quite shocked when Amodar's character model was finalized. For obvious reasons, this trope was never in effect for the English dialogue, although Lightning still wears a smile around him in *XIII* and *XIII-2*.
[Head Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadSwap): His model is a slightly modified version of the standard Cavalry trooper.
[Mr. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice): He got his difficult to model hair for this reason; looking good.
[Mercy Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MercyKill):  (SPOILER) He kills Cid on the latter's request.
[Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo): Cid's right hand.

[Satellite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatelliteCharacter): His role in the game is just as Cid's [Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo). Supplementary materials expand his behind the scenes role as one of the co-founders of Academy along with Hope's father Bartholomew.

[Sour Supporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SourSupporter): He's Cid's right hand man and supports his idealistic goal of protecting Cocoon and its people, but he's vocal in his disapproval of sacrificing his life for it.  (SPOILER) He says his page quote in the middle of what he thought would be his last stand after carrying out Cid's mercy killing.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): The game does not elaborate on his fate  (SPOILER) after he mercy kills Cid. It was implied that he is among the men made into Sacrifice Cie'th in Orphan's Cradle just prior to your arrival, but the sequel then implies he survived somehow.

[Above Good and Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AboveGoodAndEvil): The fal'Cie mostly view themselves as this and apart from the handful of them (like Barthandelus) who directly interact with and actively antagonize the playable characters, it might be true.

[Ambiguous Robots](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousRobots): Many of the fal'Cie appear to be mechanical in nature, especially Anima, but their movements give off a biological vibe. It is never stated one way or another what they truly are.

[Angelic Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngelicAbomination): They are [divine beings created by the gods](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurAngelsAreDifferent) that also created mankind and Cocoon with the express purpose of keeping the world on its axis (literally and figuratively). They have various [machine-like](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalAbomination) characteristics and come in a variety of unusual forms, ranging from [humanoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanoidAbomination) to incomprehensible.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): They collectively serve as the antagonists of the first game.

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): It's a tool's morality. Complete your Focus? Be turned into crystal until the fal'Cie revives you with a new Focus. Fail your Focus? Get turned into a zombie.
[Crystal Prison](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrystalPrison): They crystallize their l'Cie that complete their Focus. Cocoon l'Cie are encased in crystal, Pulse l'Cie turn into crystal statues.

[False Flag Operation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FalseFlagOperation):  (SPOILER) The Cocoon and Pulse fal'Cie purposefully cultivated hatred and fear between Gran Pulse and Cocoon in order to create war and open Etro's Gate.
[Gem Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GemHeart): All fal'Cie have a crystal core.

[Loophole Abuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoopholeAbuse): (SPOILER) The reason they create l'Cie is for this reason. Like l'Cie, the fal'Cie have Focuses, but they cannot deviate from or act against their Focus. Human l'Cie can, so the fal'Cie create l'Cie to have servants that can do things they can't do themselves. The ambiguous visions are often purposeful, to make manipulating their l'Cie into doing specific tasks easier.
    - Specifically, (SPOILER) the Cocoon fal'Cie can't go against their Focus to care for Cocoon and humanity, but Anima, a Pulse fal'Cie meant to defend a town on Pulse, can. There [Ain't No Rule](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AintNoRule) that a Pulse fal'Cie can't be moved to Cocoon as raw material (that was taken as a trophy of war) meant for in-Focus rebuilding efforts.

[Lovecraft Lite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovecraftLite): The non-humanoid fal'Cie tend to have physical appearances that lean towards giant seemingly inanimate objects with no discernible humanoid features (Carbuncle, for example, is just a giant floating crystal with no recognizable facial features or limbs, though it does have two faces carves into its sides).

[Mechanical Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalAbomination): While the story presents them as [angelic entities created by the setting's equivalent of God to serve his will](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngelicAbomination), their designs imply that they are a type of [Mechanical Lifeform](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalLifeforms) using [Power Crystals](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerCrystal) as batteries, created as an automation system for Gran Pulse and Cocoon.

[Mundane Utility](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MundaneUtility): Some Sanctum Fal'Cie get to be the sun. But in the Gapra Whitewood, there are numerous Fal'Cie whose sole purpose in existing is to act as an automatic door. In that context, maybe their desire for Armageddon makes a bit more sense.
[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Most fal'Cie are named for Summons in the series.

[Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad): Not all, but many of them are immobile buildings, dependent on their l'Cie or attendant fal'Cie to get things outside of their focus done. Kujata (a geothermal power plant) can't fight at all and gives out a focus that is basically "tell a PSICOM officer where the Pulse l'Cie are (then crystallize)."  (SPOILER) The Cocoon Fal'Cie in particular are blatant examples since they are unable to do anything but their ordained function, but *hate* serving humanity and are actually trying to kill off their life force just so humanity can die and they can be reunited with their creator.

[Non-Malicious Monster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonMaliciousMonster): Some of them (particularly the ones with mostly inanimate physical forms) simply mind their own business and never get directly involved in human affairs. For instance, when Lightning and Hope are standing only a few feet away from Carbuncle, it never gives any indication that it cares about or is even aware of their presence despite them technically being enemy combatants (as Pulse l'Cie while Carbuncle itself is a Cocoon fal'Cie).
[Battleship Raid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleshipRaid): See [That's No Moon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatsNoMoon).
[Floating Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FloatingLimbs): Its arms float independently of its body.

[I Let You Win](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILetYouWin): The party defeats Anima in battle at the start of the game and it immediately afterwards brands them all as l'Cie ([or teleports them elsewhere to be branded by the god Pulse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual)), suggesting they didn't actually defeat him so much as he decided to stop fighting.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): It dies right at the beginning of the game, but has the very important role of being the fal'Cie responsible for branding Serah and all six playable party members and turning them into l'Cie, thus kicking off the entire main story.
[Starter Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarterVillain): The instigator of the conflicts for the first two chapters of the game, but it's just the beginning of the larger plot.

[That's No Moon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatsNoMoon): While you do not fight the entire structure, Anima was actually the entire Pulse Vestige. This is most apparent in one of the flashbacks when the face of the Vestige roars. The boss that the game and Datalog call "Anima" was actually just its core.
[Attack of the 50-Foot Whatever](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackOfThe50FootWhatever): The Adamantoises and variants that tower over the party? They're the size of his *fingers*.
[Optional Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalBoss): Titan's trials pit the party against them as sidequests.

[The Social Darwinist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialDarwinist): His mission is to create strong species that can survive on Gran Pulse. To do so, he eats or otherwise destroys species he decides are weak, and creates new, stronger ones.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream):  (SPOILER) It wasn't until Barthandelus's death that Orphan was truly "born"; until then he existed in a sort of in-between state, aware but unable to take action as the other fal'Cie took their power from him.
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS):  (SPOILER) Its shell *is* one, and it rises up into the air to use it for [Merciless Judgment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak).
[Big Bad Duumvirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadDuumvirate): With Barthandelus. Though he doesn’t show up until the climax as Barthandelus is more active than him.
[Clipped-Wing Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClippedWingAngel):  (SPOILER) In comparison to his monstrous first form, his true form is quite tame .

[Cold-Blooded Torture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdBloodedTorture):  (SPOILER)  Tortures Fang and Vanille to provoke one into become Ragnarok. Even worse, it heals them each time so it can do so again.

[Cosmic Keystone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CosmicKeystone): Orphan is this for all of Cocoon, being the power source that keeps it running and afloat in the sky as well as the wellspring of lifeforce for all the other Cocoon Fal'Cie to draw from to keep Cocoon running. (SPOILER) Oprhan is also a suicidal example of the trope since the big plan for the Fal'Cie and Orphan is for Orphan to finally die and take all humanity and Cocoon Fal'cie with him.

[Creepy Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyChild): Has a childlike face in the middle of an angelic wheel. [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) says when he was designing Orphan, one of two guidelines he had was that its true form have such a face.

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker):  (SPOILER) He's spent centuries trapped in a sort of un-life state of [And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream). When he's finally "born," he's ready to die.

[Evil Orphan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOrphan): The clue is in his name. His whole motif is based on this, his first form having a loving mother and father incorporated into his designs and his final [Clipped-Wing Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClippedWingAngel) true form having the visage of only of a child abandoned by the parental figures. It also factors into the lore, where he was apparently forgotten and abandoned by the Maker and other fal'Cie.
[Eye Beams](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeBeams): He can spawn a single gigantic eye solely for this purpose.
[Fan Disservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FanDisservice):  (SPOILER) He has a creepy giant, serpentine woman caressing him through the whole final battle .

[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss):  (SPOILER) Orphan is the final boss of *FFXIII*, with his two forms making up stages 2 & 3 of the final encounter after Barthandelus is defeated for the third time and absorbed onto him.
[Gold and White Are Divine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldAndWhiteAreDivine): It's a massive white and silver fal'Cie inside a golden wheel.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain):  (SPOILER) Has been used by all the other fal'Cie as Cocoon's [Living Battery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingBattery), making him to blame for Cocoon existing at all, yet he technically wasn't "born" until the final phase of the game.

tropeName: Heads I Win, Tails You Lose
tropeNotes: [Heads I Win, Tails You Lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadsIWinTailsYouLose):  (SPOILER) The multi-phase final boss battle doesn't count for him. He just turns messing with the hero party again. Luckily he gets mauled another cutscene later.
[I Am Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmLegion):  (SPOILER) When fused with Barthandelus and a representation of Lindzei, he speaks with layered voices.

[I Cannot Self-Terminate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ICannotSelfTerminate):  (SPOILER) The premise. If he could, there would be no need to train l'Cie, the main party, into killing him. So there would be no game .

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass):  (SPOILER)  In just one scene, *Barthandelus* looks nice in comparison. He mocks the party after his boss fight, laughs as the party become cie'th and beat up Fang, proclaims miracles to be born out of misery, and tortures and heals her after she fails to kill them. Even assuming the shell of Barthandelus and the Lindzei image aren't Orphan speaking, the first words out of the mouth on that childish face is a disdainful proclamation that the party is trying for something they can never achieve.
[Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood): Like Barthandelus, his powers are light-based.
[Living MacGuffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingMacGuffin):  (SPOILER) He, or rather his death, is what Barthandelus spends most of the game grooming and manipulating the party for.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName):
    - As invoked by Orphan himself, he is the Abandoned One, created by the Maker to power Cocoon and then left in a state of un-life and forgotten about. (SPOILER) His design was also made to invoke the idea that when his shell is destroyed and you face his true form, his "parents" in the shell have abandoned him to fight alone . - Orphan also ties into the "Ophanim", singular form "Ophan", a class of angels also known as Thrones for they carry the throne of god, and are depicted as giant flaming wheels covered in eyes.
[Mechanical Lifeform](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalLifeform): The fal'Cie are all these, machine like gods powered by a magical crystal.

[My Name Is Inigo Montoya](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyNameIsInigoMontoya):
    - " (SPOILER) We are the Abandoned One, born but now to die. Our name is Orphan! By our hand, the world shall know redemption! " - Additionally, the [very impressive music](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/SugarWiki/AwesomeMusic) that plays when he appears for the first time has an *extremely* big, dramatic, and loud opening, and the translation of the choir's [Latin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OminousLatinChanting) is "My name is Orphan! ORPHAN!"
[No-Sell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSell):  (SPOILER) He's completely immune to all damage in his final form, until you Stagger him.

[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill):
    - (SPOILER) His final form has only one attack besides Doom, which he casts at the beginning of the battle, and repeatedly casts Death. - (SPOILER) Also, it's possible to slaughter him with Vanille's Death if you're lucky .

[Our Angels Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurAngelsAreDifferent): Easily the most angelic-looking of the fal'Cie, as much as he can while still clearly being a [Mechanical Lifeform](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechanicalLifeform) anyway.

[Powered by a Forsaken Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoweredByAForsakenChild): He *is* the forsaken child powering Cocoon. Which is why  (SPOILER) he is out to destroy himself .
QUOTE **Orphan:** A haven, yea. Yet it must fall ere we be saved. Too frail a shell, and humans should not thrive. Too stout a shell, and they would not die. Slaughter and salvation! Two irreconcilable focuses we bore. Yet bound were we in a cocoon prison, impervious to our power.
[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss):  (SPOILER) Orphan has two forms that need to be destroyed, with a long cutscene between them.
[Slasher Smile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlasherSmile):  (SPOILER) Right before the final battle.
[Straw Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawNihilist): As noted by Lightning,  (SPOILER) it gave up on living before it was even really alive.

tropeName: Strike Me Down with All of Your Hatred!
tropeNotes:
[Strike Me Down with All of Your Hatred!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrikeMeDownWithAllOfYourHatred):  (SPOILER) Perks up excitedly when Fang turns into Ragnarok and taps into her [Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage) .
QUOTE **Orphan:** Yes! Let anger be your strength! Despair! Despair and save us all! Lo! The day of wrath has come!
[Timed Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimedMission):  (SPOILER) Casts Doom on the party leader in the final battle, though with a much higher timer than usual.
[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion):  (SPOILER) His shell speaks in male and female voices in unison, and refer to themselves in the plural.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler):  (SPOILER) He's the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) of the game, and is a [Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker) as eager to die as Barthandelus and to have the party kill him.

[Woobie, Destroyer of Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds):  (SPOILER) Unlike Barthandelus, Orphan has been trapped in a purgatorial, tormented, "unborn" state for centuries, giving him ample personal reason to be a [Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker).

[Yin-Yang Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YinYangBomb):  (SPOILER) His first form is encased in a shell made of a light and gold image of a female Lindzei on the right, and a dark blue and black image of Barthandelus on the left. He also has the debuffing skill Consummate Darkness and the buffing skill Consummate Light .

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): She's never mentioned in the games proper with the exception of a single Fragment in *XIII-2.* In the Japanese version of *Lightning Returns*, Bhunivelze makes off-hand mention of her to Lightning as the world's destroyer whom he defeated, but never says her name except in the [Bhunivelze+](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueFinalBoss) fight on Hard Mode, where he references humanity as her children.
[Antagonistic Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntagonisticOffspring): Got offed by her boy.
[Death by Origin Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByOriginStory): She was dead long before the events of the trilogy even started.

[Death of the Old Gods](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathOfTheOldGods): Her death paved the way for Bhunivelze to become the [Top God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TopGod) of [The 'Verse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVerse).

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): Despite her son's attempt to suppress and erase her, not only did she take a long time to actually die, but out of all the deities, only she and Etro retain any sort of physical presence in the new world after *Lightning Returns*. Lindzei, Bhunivelze, and Pulse all only exist in memories while Etro and Mwynn's likeness live on in Yeul.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): The word *Mwyn* means "gentle" or "kind" in Welsh.

[Not Quite Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotQuiteDead): Bhunivelze always suspected that she wasn't dead yet, which was why he tasked Pulse to find the Door of Souls that led to the Unseen Realm. Turns out Etro found Mwynn first (thanks to her committing suicide and being sent to the Unseen Realm) and discovered Mwynn *was* still alive... of a sort. She got devoured by the Chaos, but managed to give Etro one final task.

[Order Versus Chaos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrderVersusChaos): She tasked Etro with preserving the balance between the two Realms, and if this balance should ever be broken, [the universe would end.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApocalypseHow) This was absolutely proven right when said balance was shattered at the end of *[Final Fantasy XIII-2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIII2)*.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): She is this in the first two games. Unlike the fal'Cie and her siblings, Etro loves humanity instead of viewing them as tools and will frequently step in to help them should her intervention be needed, such as  (SPOILER)  when she reversed the parties Cie'th transformations and freed them from Crystal Stasis.

[Character Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDeath): As of the ending of the second game,  (SPOILER) her heart is pierced, causing the Chaos to flow between worlds and creating the setting for the third and final game.

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): The pictures of her in *[Final Fantasy XV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXV)* has her in all black, but she, inadvertently, created humanity and gave them their heart. Mind you [the powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperEmpowering) she may elect to further bless humanity with [aren't all that great](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlessedWithSuck), but that's not her own fault.
[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): Being powerless compared to Pulse and Lindzei as well as thinking of Mwynn caused her to cross it in the myth.

[Deus ex machina](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeusExMachina): (SPOILER)  Specifically, her Deus Ex Machina actions at the end of *[Final Fantasy XIII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIII)* break the laws of reality, which causes a [Time Crash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeCrash) and unleashes Chaos into the world, which Etro must attempt to seal at the cost of her life.

[Divine Intervention](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DivineIntervention): She often takes pity on humanity in their struggles.  (SPOILER)  *[Final Fantasy XIII-2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIII2)* confirms that the ending of *[Final Fantasy XIII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIII)*, in which the party members were de-crystallized and had their l'Cie brands removed, was the direct result of her intervention. This intervention came with a high price...

[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide): Thanks to her [Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon) where she tore at her own body but thanks to that humanity was born from her blood.

[Enigmatic Empowering Entity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnigmaticEmpoweringEntity): She has gifted Lightning with godlike power, as well as granting Yeul and Serah with her eyes allowing them to see the future *and* Caius with her heart; granting him immortality.

[God Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodIsGood): Her mercy is frequently commented on and Yeul says that, unlike the Fal'cie, she grants super powers without turning people into slaves.  (SPOILER)  The [Cast from Lifespan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromLifespan) aspect is not her fault.

[God Is Inept](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodIsInept): She tries to help but has a hard time doing anything without  (SPOILER) breaking reality, as shown by her [Deus ex machina](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeusExMachina) at the end of the first game.

[The Gods Must Be Lazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGodsMustBeLazy): Inverted. Etro causes problems by being too active.  (SPOILER)  Saving the heroes from their crystalized fate and reuniting them with their loved ones at the end of the first game distorts the 'true' timeline which directly leads to the death of Yeul. Yeul is a seeress whose visions shorten her life span and the distortions in time increase the frequency of her visions which leads to a premature death. This motivates Caius to become the second game's Big Bad. The power to see visions was given to her by Etro to better govern her city. The only thing she did that did NOT backfire was choose Lightning to be her champion.
[Guardian Entity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuardianEntity): Etro's duty is to watch over the Door of Souls.

tropeName: He Who Must Not Be Seen
tropeNotes: [He Who Must Not Be Seen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWhoMustNotBeSeen): Like Lindzei we never see Etro, only a painting of her in *[Final Fantasy XV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXV)* and on murals in *Lightning Returns*.
[Identical Grandson](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalGrandson): Etro is said to be identical to her creator's mother Mwynn.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): She was powerless compared to Lindzei and Pulse, having been discarded because she resembled Mwynn, Bhunivelze's mother. However, she turned out  (SPOILER)  to be the most important of the gods, as she maintained the cycle of life, death, and rebirth, preventing the destruction of the world .
[Nice Job Breaking It, Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero):  (SPOILER) Etro broke the timeline when she awoke the main party from crystal stasis at the end of the original game.

[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): This varies depending on the language. The English version of Lightning Returns always refers to Lindzei as male, but his gender remains unspecified in the original Japanese. In addition, many of the representations and descriptions of Lindzei in the original Final Fantasy XIII describe Lindzei as a motherly figure, implying a female gender.

[Animal Motifs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalMotifs): Snakes. Pulsian belief casts Cocoon as a "floating nest of vipers", and the mark of Lindzei resembles a cobra.  (SPOILER) The motherly figure on Orphan's first form, representative of Lindzei, has a long, serpentine body.

[Final Solution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalSolution):  (SPOILER)  Lindzei and his Fal'Cie children Barthandelus, Orphan, and [Gala](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyType0) seem to like commiting mass genocide. While Lindzei's reasons are unknown the others attempted it to open the Door of Souls.

[Guardian Entity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuardianEntity):  (SPOILER) According to the mythology, Lindzei was made to be the protector of Pulse. [Clearly his fal'Cie didn't get the memo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColonyDrop).
[Have You Seen My God?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HaveYouSeenMyGod):  (SPOILER)  His disappearance is what drives the antagonist's actions.

tropeName: He Who Must Not Be Seen
tropeNotes: [He Who Must Not Be Seen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWhoMustNotBeSeen): We never actually see Lindzei, although it's represented by a symbol and various statues.
[The Maker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMaker): He created Cocoon, the Cocoon Fal'cie as well as humanity itself out of his sister Etro's blood.
[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment):  (SPOILER) He was a parental figure to the Cocoon fal'cie and abandoned them long before the game begins.

[Riddle for the Ages](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiddleForTheAges): Why did Lindzei abandon Cocoon? Doubles as a bit of a [Driving Question](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivingQuestion),  (SPOILER) especially to the Cocoon fal'Cie. Whether or not Lindzei is The Maker is also a bit of a puzzle.

[Satanic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatanicArchetype): A purportedly serpentine deity who created individual will in humanity and tempted many of them into abandoning Gran Pulse for the much more hedonistic Cocoon, eventually leading the two realms to war - all of this is similar to the Biblical war between Yhwh and Satan after the latter gave humans free will and they (and Satan) were banished from heaven.

[Sigil Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SigilSpam): Lindzei's mark is prominent throughout Cocoon, such as the head Dysley's [Staff of Authority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StaffOfAuthority) as well as Dajh  (SPOILER) and Cid's  l'cie brands. It is essentially Cocoon and Sanctum's 'flag'.
[Satan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Satan): To the people of Pulse, at any rate. The viper comparisons really drive it home.
[For Doom the Bell Tolls](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForDoomTheBellTolls): He seems to be made up of church bells!

tropeName: He Who Must Not Be Seen
tropeNotes: [He Who Must Not Be Seen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWhoMustNotBeSeen): Averted. Unlike Lindzei or Etro, we actually see Pulse.
[Our Gods Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurGodsAreDifferent): His appearance in his [one scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneSceneWonder) is quite bizarre to say the least.

[Parental Neglect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalNeglect):  (SPOILER) Pulse was a parental figure to the Gran Pulse fal'Cie and abandoned them long before the game begins. His reasons for doing so are unknown.

[Riddle for the Ages](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiddleForTheAges): Like Lindzei he disappeared from the people of Gran Pulse.  (SPOILER)  Though what his goals are is unknown, his servant [Arecia Al-Rashia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyType0) attempted to open the Door of Souls using special souls.

[Action Heroine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionHeroine): Throughout the games she takes down countless [Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mooks) and destroys armies, aircrafts, and trains, all with [quite some grace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar).

[Affectionate Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname): In the Japanese dialogue, Snow calls her "[nee-san](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/JapaneseSiblingTerminology)" ("big sis") - as in "sister-in-law." Lightning dislikes this immensely.
    - While she did tell Hope to call her "Light" instead of him coming up with it himself it still counts since it indicates that she's warming up to him. Later, many of her friends, including Snow, refer to Lightning as "Light".

[Aloof Big Sister](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AloofBigBrother): She's very protective of Serah, but she concentrates so much on shielding her from *physical* harm that she neglects areas like friendliness or affection.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): Starts as an [Unscrupulous Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnscrupulousHero), very briefly dabbles in being a [Nominal Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NominalHero) after her [Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton) is smashed into oblivion, and transitions into a [Pragmatic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticHero) about halfway through when she regains her senses and undergoes [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).

[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): The red cape dangling off her left shoulder is implied to *not* be Guardian Corps standard. Fortunately, she's fired during peaceful times that mean it's acceptable wear.
[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): Look at the first cutscene, which is *before* she becomes a l'Cie. She takes on robots, monsters and Anima casually.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): With Snow only, she doesn't take kindly to him calling her "Sis". Mostly because she doesn't approve of him at first (and also because it's not technically true until the wedding).
[BFS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BFS): In Gestalt mode, Lightning gets use of Odin's utterly monstrous sword Zantetsuken.

[Bifauxnen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bifauxnen):
    - Not in-game, but in a cross-promotion. She appeared in Japanese men's fashion magazine *Arena Homme Plus* modeling Prada's mens' summer collection. - A few costumes in the third game put her in suits, putting this trope into full effect.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): She is arguably this of the entire FF XIII trilogy despite her character flaws. In *XIII* She leads the party to stop Barthandelus and Orphan from destroying cocoon and it’s inhabitants, In *XIII-2* She becomes the chosen champion of the goddess Etro to stop Caius Ballad from killing the goddess and in *Lightning Returns* she becomes the savior of the world by saving souls and bringing them to the new world, she even stops the God of light Bhunivelze from controlling the humans of the new world and turning them into his emotionless puppets.
[Big Sister Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigSisterInstinct): For all of her faults, she's quite protective of Serah.
[Big Sister Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigSisterMentor): She acts as one for Hope and teaches him how to survive in the wild.

[A Birthday, Not a Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ABirthdayNotABreak): Serah and Snow broke the news that Serah had become a l'Cie *and* accepted Snow's marriage proposal to Lightning during her birthday party. Lightning [dismissed their story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CassandraTruth) and forced Snow and Serah to leave her home, openly declaring it to be the "[worst birthday ever](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorstWhateverEver)." Unfortunately, by the Lightning realized that Serah was telling her the truth, it was too late: the Purge of Bodhum had begun, and Serah had been taken captive by the fal'Cie that branded her.

[Blade Brake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeBrake): Thrown in an uncontrolled manner by a massive Behemoth? No problem for Lightning. She'll just slam her gunblade into the ground with a single arm while flipping backwards and then proceed to steady herself quickly enough to pull off a badass pose seconds later before engaging in battle.

[Broken Bird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenBird): Lightning's opinion about her moniker at the start of the game is that it reflects how destructive "Lightning" has been in regards her relationship with her sister, Serah.
[By-the-Book Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ByTheBookCop): One of the reasons she had such a problem with Snow was because she saw him as a jobless law-breaking thug.

[Character Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterFocus): *Final Fantasy XIII* only came out at the end of 2009, but Lightning has made several appearances in other media. She's not only appeared in several spin-offs, but her outfit appears as a promotional bonus outfit for *[The 3rd Birthday](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/The3rdBirthday)* and *[Final Fantasy XIV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV)*, she's the leader of the new heroes in *[Dissidia 012 Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)*, and she appears in the "Long Live Play" commercials for the Playstation 3. About the only domain left is a *[Kingdom Hearts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/KingdomHearts)* showing.

[Combat Parkour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatParkour): She's very acrobatic in cutscenes (back-flipping, leap-frogging over people, hopping from airship to airship during Chapter 12, etc.) as well as during combat (Army of One is full of flips and other feats and her normal combo has her backflipping while firing her gunblade).

[Cool Big Sis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolBigSis):
    - Serah's. Along with the [overprotectiveness, strength, and lack of social grace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct) normally given to big *brothers.* Heck, *[Snow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBigGuy)* calls her "Nee-san"! (Although in his case it is a reference to her being his (future) sister-in-law.) - To Hope, she's either this or a [Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute). - Sazh refers to her as 'nee-chan' once in a while, though in his case it's less straightforward. The only time he actually says it to Lightning's face is when they've just met and he doesn't know her name — in Japan, addressing strangers as sister/aunt/grandmother depending on their age is pretty common. The rest of the time, he's talking to the others about her, which can be seen as Sazh encouraging them to think of Lightning as such.

[A God I Am Not](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodIAmNot): During the Bahamut vs. Bahamut battle, Noel asks if she's the goddess in Valhalla. Lightning's response is a gentle, but firm "I never said I was a goddess."
[Air Jousting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AirJousting): With Caius during the opening.

tropeName: Ascend to a Higher Plane of Existence
tropeNotes: [Ascend to a Higher Plane of Existence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendToAHigherPlaneOfExistence): She has been pulled to the world of Valhalla (A.K.A. Land of the Dead) to protect Goddess Etro's temple.

[Be All My Sins Remembered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeAllMySinsRemembered): Lightning considers her entire situation in Final Fantasy XIII-2 as something she deserves and feels that it will serve as her way to atone for all of her past sins.

[Being Good Sucks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeingGoodSucks): Caius even tells her in The Fragments After that she could live out her life with her friends and family in happiness without anything bad happening until hundreds of years later. However, she couldn't live with herself and knows that she could never face her loved ones by making such a choice, so instead  (SPOILER)  She goes though endless 900 year loops fighting each and every day of her life in an unending, ultimately lost war .
[The Beastmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBeastmaster): The game's introduction shows her as [The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader) of an army of monsters.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): As [The Champion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChampion) for the benevolent deity in this story, she is the highest authority, the ones Serah looks up to, and the only one that can truly match Cauis in battle.
[Blade Lock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BladeLock): With Caius in their battles because they are equally matched.

[Chainmail Bikini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainmailBikini): [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope), but her Knight of Etro armour is designed to offer protection without affecting her [acrobatic ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheFu). This means a chestplate, gauntlets, greaves, and pauldrons, but exposed joints and no codpiece (the feathery sash helps cover up a bit more).
[Cool Horse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolHorse): Odin, of course, though he only appears in the prologue.
[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): The one she has in the first game is upgraded by Etro along with her armor.

[Decoy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecoyProtagonist): Though she has a short DLC episode in the form of "Requiem of the Goddess" to explain her side of the story a bit more, this game is very much about Serah.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): She has a scene in the prologue, provides narration at the start of most chapters, and  (SPOILER) gets a brief meeting with Serah in New Bodhum 700 AF , but otherwise she has no screen time outside of her DLC episode.

[Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke): In her Knight of Etro armour, Lightning is a Commando with stats at *level 1* comparable to Twilight Odin's stats at *level 90*. The only thing standing between the player and the complete Ruinga of the difficulty curve is a spoiler alert.

[Feather Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeatherMotif): Her costume and her gunblade summoning now involve copious amounts of feathers. [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) confirms that this symbolizes a connection to the divine.
[Fluffy Fashion Feathers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FluffyFashionFeathers): As part of her new Etro's Champion armor.
[Futile Hand Reach](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FutileHandReach):  (SPOILER) To Serah during the Requiem of the Goddess DLC.

[Gravity Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GravityMaster): One of the quick time events during the opening allows for Lightning to use the Graviga spell... which causes all of the surrounding sheets of metal and scrap to collapse in on Caius, crushing him. He doesn't die. This is considered the less favorable outcome compared to the Ruinga option.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): (SPOILER) Lightning is crystallized in the ending in order to protect Serah's will, according to [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod).

[Heroic Vow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicVow): "I made my choice. I will fight... I will never give up"  (SPOILER)  This entails fighting an unwinnable battle for countless 900 year loops in which she remembers each one; leading army after army into battle; protecting every single last human across all the timelines, in every point in history; and essentially chains her to a life of death, sorrow, and hardship on top of precluding her from ever being with those she loves and cares about... heroic indeed.

[Hero of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroOfAnotherStory): The fragments hint at many adventures in Valhalla and imply that she built the army seen in the prologue by fighting every single monster composing it.
[Hyperspace Arsenal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HyperspaceArsenal): Calls her new gunblade from thin air.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): Clearing the DLC earns Lightning as a Paradigm Pack ally; one of her victory quotes if she gets the last kill is "I hope I did my part." Except that the difficulty of her DLC is independent of the difficulty of the main game, and Lightning is on par with most of the allies one can get at the Coliseum. If one ignores the spoiler warning and beats *Requiem of the Goddess* as soon as they have access to the Historia Crux, Lightning is a [Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke) that will *slaughter* **everything**.
[Legally Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegallyDead): Believed dead or crystal by everyone but Serah because of changes in the timeline. Snow and Hope eventually realize that's not the case.
[All-Loving Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllLovingHero): Her task has ultimately changed her into this. She tries to help everyone and bring the best out of everyone she meets.

[Ambiguously Human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyHuman): Lightning is unsure whether she's still human after her crystallization.  (SPOILER) In addition, she states numerous times that at points where she *should* feel something, she isn't, and doesn't really care. Even a vision of Serah didn't get emotion out of her, she noted, and is justifiably worried. The truth zigzags this trope — she's become powerful enough to be considered a goddess in her own right, but the real reason her emotions are dampened is because Bhunivelze extracted part of her soul when he made her the Savior.
[Apocalypse Maiden](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApocalypseMaiden): The [Children of Etro](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cult) view her as the harbinger of the impending apocalypse.

[Armor Is Useless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorIsUseless): Subverted; her outfits range from showy fabric to plate mail; her default Equilibrium outfit would properly be considered "leather armour". How much damage she takes without guarding is dependent on her equipment abilities, *not* the design of her ensemble. How much damage she takes *while* guarding is dependent on her shield and ability stats.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): She doesn't think much of (SPOILER) Noel's attempt to challenge her. QUOTE *[Bring It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BringIt) on, (SPOILER) Noel . I've been [fighting destiny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewDestiny) for a long time now, and I'm getting good at it.*
    - Another example is Bhunivelze's challenge.
QUOTE "I'll become a Goddess of death, all right. But not the one you want. I'll be the Goddess who kills you!"

[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): While what she wears in her default "Savior of the World" outfit can't actually be called a coat or a [Badass Long Robe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongRobe), it's clearly designed to invoke the imagery of one. Some of her other outfits have the more traditional longcoat or robe.

[Broken Bird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenBird): In an [interview](http://www.polygon.com/2013/8/21/4644112/lightning-returns-a-more-vulnerable-heroine-running-out-of-time), Yuji Abe and Motomu Toriyama state that Lightning is less rough and stoic than previous games due to her [Guilt Complex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuiltComplex) finally [catching up to her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon), and that some players might interpret that as her being more feminine.

[Cool Shades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolShades): She wears these in the opening, and can later obtain them as an adornment, in addition to some other ones. [It's nighttime when she wears them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SunglassesAtNight) in the opening, and she can wear them at nighttime as well.
[The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne): She is the Savior chosen by God (I.E. Bhunivelze) to appear at the end of the world to save the souls of humanity.

[Don't You Dare Pity Me!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DontYouDarePityMe): She reveals in the "Stolen Things" sidequest that she always despised how people pitied her for being an orphan when she was young, so she walled away her emotions and worked to become [The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic).

[Dude Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DudeMagnet): She gets a lot of compliments from guys she meets about her looks throughout her quest. One even goes so far to ask her out on a date, which the player has an option to agree or not.
[Emotionless Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmotionlessGirl): Lightning suspects God removed her emotions and Hope's to better go about their mission.

[Even the Girls Want Her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenTheGirlsWantHer): If she's wearing one of the "suit" style garbs, passing by some women can cause them to remark "[He's a cutie!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bifauxnen)" Other outfits like her [Sphere Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyX2) outfit go right into the trope with women complimenting her legs and saying, "Sexy!" as she runs by.

[Fanservice Pack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FanservicePack): Square Enix increased the size of Lightning's breasts for this game since there would be outfits in that would show off more of her body than what players were used to seeing from her.

[Futile Hand Reach](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FutileHandReach):  (SPOILER) During the last day, she grabs for Hope's hand...and hers goes right through his as he starts to [Disappear Into Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearsIntoLight).

[Hates Being Touched](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HatesBeingTouched): After her reunion with Mog, Lightning gives this reason as to why she flicked him away instead of letting him hug her.
QUOTE  **Lightning:** "I couldn't help it. I just reacted out of instinct. I don't go in for people hugging me. Or moogles. Even if I'm glad to see them."

[The Heroine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeroine): While her main motive for helping God save the souls' of humans is to save Serah, she still generally displays quite a lot of heroism throughout her quest, moreso than she ever has before - from helping anyone in need to encouraging anyone having a difficult time, and even making occasional quotes in battle such as "I fight to give people hope!" and "Evil has a price!". Fairly justified in that doing so helps her power grow.  (SPOILER)  By the end of the game, she's undoubtedly a true heroine, risking everything to face the most powerful evil God in the universe to give all people a chance in the new world.  Ultimately, she has ascended from being an anti-heroine from the first game into a true heroine.

[Hero with Bad Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWithBadPublicity): She's originally accused as being an evil savior by everyone when she first starts her quest in Luxerion, and Noel tries to kill her. Her heroic actions later change his and the others' mind.

[Hidden Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenHeartOfGold): She clearly wants to do the right things and help others deep down, even if she claims to only be doing it for her sister.  (SPOILER)  Proven for certain at the end, as she risks everything to kill the evil God Bhunivelze who only wants to let people whom he deems worthy live in his new world and kill the rest, and take his place as a new Goddess whom will allow a new world for everyone.

[Messianic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MessianicArchetype): The savior of the world awakened from death to bring innocent souls to a new and better world.
